page.title: When do two sets have the same size?

html.p: Q: When do two sets `A` and `B` have the same size?
A: (Kind of.) Cantor said that two sets have the same size when the elements of the two sets can be paired off.

html.def: If `A, B` are sets, then a function `f: A \to B` is a mapping that assigns to each `x \in A` a unique element `f(x) \in B`.

def.p:
Define the inverse image of a subset `D \subset B`,
\\[ f^{-1}(D) = \{ x \in A : f(x) \in D \}. \\]

Dfn: Two set `A` and `B` have the same cardinality if there exists a bijective function `f: A \to B`
Short hand notation, when two sets have the same caridinality, we write
1) `|A| = |B|`
2) if `|A| = |{1, ..., n}| we write `|A| = n`.
3) if there exists injective function `f:A \to B` we write `|A| \le |B|`.
4) if `|A| \le |B|` but `|A| \ne |B|` we write `|A| \lt |B|`.

if |A| \le |B| and |B| \le |A| then |A| = |B|
theorem cantor_schroder_bernstein (A B: Set) : card A \le card B \and card B \le card A \to card A = card B
